coredata.dc:title: Xanes studies of bis-1-oxopyridine-2-thiolato Pt(II) complexes
coredata.dc:creator: Russo, M.V.
Furlani, A.
Davoli, I.
Bianconi, A.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) studies at the L3 Pt edge for the Pt(II) complexes [Pt(SONC5H4)2] and [Pt4(SONC5H4)5Cl3] are presented. The variation of coordination charge of Pt, depending on the electron withdrawing effect of the ligands and coordination geometry, is discussed.

Italy Dipartimento di Matematica € Fisica, Universita di Camerino, 62032 Camerino, italy Centro lnteruniversitario di Strurtura del/a Materia (CISM), Dipartimento a? Fisica, Universita di Room La Sapienza 00185 Rome, Italy and Universita deli A que/a, Collemaggio, 67100 L .4quila, Italy Received 4 October 1988; in final form 7 January 1989 X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) studies at the L3 Pt edge fur the Pt (Ii) complexes ~Pt ( SONC,H4 ) 2] and [Pt4 ( SONC5H4 )5Cl3 J are presented. The variation of coordination charge of Pt, depending on the electron withdrawing effect of the ligands and coordination geometry, is discussed. edge is proportional to the d-electron vacancies. In this paper the coordination charges on Pt are esti- mated for seven complexes having different envi- ronments and therefore different chemical properties. 2. Experimental Complexes A and B (see fig. 1) were prepared ac- cording to a literature method [7] and purified be- fore use, as well as standard complexes: K2PtC14, K.2PtC16 [9]; cis-[Pt(C~CPh)2(PPh3)2] (cis I) [10], trans-[Pt(CwCPh)2(PPh3)2] (trans 1) (11], cis-[Pt(C~C C(CH3)2OH]2(PPh3)2] (cis 2) [12], trans- [Pt(C~C C(CH3)2OH)2(PPh3)2] (trans 2) [11]. Pt02 (Adams catalyst) is a commercial prod- uct (Carlo Erba). The experiments were performed at room tem- perature in transmission at the Frascati Synchrotron Radiation Facility (PULS), using X-rays emitted by the 1.5 GeV storage ring Adone. The X-rays were monochromatized by a silicon (1 t 1) channel-cut crystal with resolution of about 3 eV. The samples were powdered and spread on a Kapton tape. Par- ticular attention was paid in order to avoid pin-holes and to ensure a cored normalization. I. Introduction Metallic complexes of pyridine N-oxides are in- teresting for their activity as antifungal [1] and an- tibacterial (2,3] agents. The tautomeric ligand 1-ox- idopyridinium-2-thiol shows a peculiar behaviour because it can replace ligands which are usually inert in the coordination sphere and gives ~2 vynilic com- plexes of Mo and W [4,5]. Square-planar coordi- nation complexes of Ni, Pd and Pt have been exten- sively studied because they exhibit anisotropic physical properties, the most important one being the l-D metallic conductivity along the metal chain axis [61. Recently we prepared some Pt complexes A and B (fig. 1) which are interesting because of their reactivity with phosphine (7] and because, starting from preliminary measurements, we believe that the complex B, insoluble oligomeric Pt-polymer (Pt units a 4), could produce good semiconducting properties after doping with 2. Lytle et al. [8] have shown that the intensity of the peak at the L3 X-ray absorption A B ~ Fig. 1. Structure of complexes A (Pt(MPNO)2) and B (polynuelear). 599 Volume 155, number 6 CHEMtCAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17 March 1989 3. Results and discussion Compound A is a Pt(II) chelate complex for which a trans structure has been suggested although we can- not exclude the alternative cis form. The geometrical configuration of Pt and Pd chelate complexes is still an unresolved question, actively investigated by sev- erat groups interested in understanding the mode of action of antitumour platinum drugs [13,14]. Here we have investigated the electronic configuration of the Pt ion by L3 XANES of compounds A and B. Near-edge XANES spectra for the Pt L3 edge of complexes A and B are reported with the spectra of model compounds K2PtC14, K2PtC15 and Pta2 in fig. 2. The spectra of the model compounds are in good agreement with the results reported by MUller et al. [15], Sham [16] and Nemanova et al. [171. The spectra of K2PtCI4 and K2PtCI5 are also similar to those of analogous K2PdC14 and K2PdC16 com- pounds reported by Sogiura et al. [18]. XANES of K2PtC14 in solid and solution environ- ments have been studied recently [16] and Pt Pt in- teractions along the one-dimensional chain are suggested. The spectra of complexes A and B compared with that of K2PtCI4 show the white line intensity, indi- cating the 2p adX2_V2 transition [19] to be inter- mediate between that of K2PtC15 and K2PtCI4. Since a C I. C- a: 0 C Fig. 2. Pt L3 XANES of (a) PrO2, (b) K2PtC16, (c) K2PtCI4, (d) complex A, (e) complex H. the white line intensity is indicative of the popula- tion of the unoccupied d states, it suggests in our case a depletion of d character at the Pt site of complexes A and B with respect to K2PtC14. Other Pt complexes taken as reference have been investigated. XANES spectra of reference com- pounds cis 1, trans I, cis 2 and trans 2 are reported in fig. 3. The pattern of the XANES spectra of cis- and trans-bistriphenylphosphine Pt acetylides are very similar (see fig. 3); they are square-planar com- plexes, with P and C bonded to Pt in cis or trans con- figuration where the withdrawing effect of the alkyne ligand is expected to be more effective for the trans I complex. The most significant difference is the fact that the intensity ratio, r, between the white line and the av- erage continuum in the XANES region is larger for compounds a and b (r=1.92 0.02) than for com- pounds c and d (r= 1.63 0.02) (fig, 3). This result shows the effect of the changing ligands for Pt charge depletion. Coordination charge has been determined using a simple concept: there is a different strength of the threshold resonance in the presence of different Ii- gands. This model assumes that as d electrons flow into chemical bonds and become delocalized from the parent metal atom, the resulting Pt d-elec- tron vacancy will be mapped by the L3 absorption a 0 a a: 0 U-, C Fig. 3. Pt L3 XANESof (a) cit t, (b) trans 1, (c) cis2, (d) trans 2. 20 4.0 - Photon Energy(eV) 0 20 40 60 Photon Energy 1eV) 600 Volume 155, numberS CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17 March 1989 transition [20,21]. In fig. 4 an example of the cal- culation for the area of the white line is reported for the complex cis 2. The smooth absorption coefficient due to 2p *Ed transitions to unoccupied continuum states at energy e can be described by an arctangent curve [22,23]. We have subtracted from the L3 absorption spec- trum of the reference complex cis 2 an arctangent curve, to simulate the absorption jump from the pre- edge value to the atomic value of the absorption coefficient above the edge. The residue of the sub- traction is shown in fig. 4 (dotted line), where a good lit of the residue of the cia 2 spectrum by a single Lorentzian has been obtained. Using references compounds for 7A we have de- termined the slope of the calibration curve IA versus L3 white line area; the coordination charge of the compounds A, B, cis 1, cis 2, trans 1 and trans 2 are measured by the area of their white lines using the calibration curve in fig. 5. The trend of the coordi- nation charge, for our samples fits with the charge which is expected to be on the Pt atom depending on the chemical properties of the ligands. In fact the C6H5 radical bonded to a C~C bond gives a small electron flow to the platinum, while the electron donor CH3 group exerts an inductive effect; better electron donors are sulfur and oxygen, the latter being even more effective because of a negative charge given by the mercapto-pyridinc-N-oxide ligand. Cal- culations performed on our complexes, taking into 5 10 AREA aA ar b.unjts} Fig. 5. Coordination charge versus area or the white line; refer- ence compounds ( ), measured values ( ). account only the first shell of atoms bonded to Pt, give lA values lower than that of K2PtCI4, while the higher experimental values show the effect of the electron delocalization due to the chemical structure in A and B. tt is well known [241 that Pt Pt interaction (con- ductivity) increases significantly in one-dimensional Pt compounds as the oxidation state of Pt becomes greater than two. According to the interpretation of XANES spectra reported by Sham [16], the nature of the Pt Pt interaction in solid K2PtC14 involves Pt d~2 (peak 2 , fig. 2c) and ~ d5~ (peak 2) states, upon overlapping in a [PtCl4]~ chain. hi our case (fig. 2e) the spectrum of complex B, which shows a XANES spectral feature more like that of [PtCl4 }2_ [16], would indicate more a d~2, d52 character; the small extent of states having d72 character may be due to a distortion of the square-planar structure. The results obtained from L3 XANES spectra of complexes A and B show that both have square- planar geometry. For the polynuclear B a distortion from planarity is observed and a d-electron vacancy which is intermediate between that of K2PtC14 and K2PtCI6 therefore the proposed structure encour- ages us to believe that it could be a suitable con- ducting material [25] after doping. 601 / , Pt02 transl UI a: C = 1.0 LI a 0 ~0.5 C a: 0 C Li K2PtC10,../ /4 0 10(QV) 20 Fig. 4. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) studies at the L3 Pt edge for the Pt(II) complexes [Pt(SONC5H4)2] and [Pt4(SONC5H4)5Cl3] are presented. The variation of coordination charge of Pt, depending on the electron withdrawing effect of the ligands and coordination geometry, is discussed.
